questions.question: They ………………………. come in the evening. (weak possibility)
questions.description: May indicates possibility might indicates very weak possibility. Can is not used in affirmative clauses to talk about possibility.

questions.question: She ………………….. know his address. (possibility)
questions.description: Might is also possible here but it indicates weak possibility.

questions.question: ………………………. you speak English? (ability)
questions.description: Can shows ability.

questions.question: If you spoke English, you ………………………. get a better job. (ability)
questions.description: In type 2 conditional sentences, we use could, not can, to show ability.

questions.question: You ……………………… be watching too many films.
I …………………….. now. (strong obligation)
questions.description: Modals are followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: The roof ………………………. be repaired one of these days.
questions.description: Either must or ought to is possible here. Ought is followed by an infinitive with to.

questions.question: I ………………………… work really hard in those days.
questions.description: Modals do not normally have past forms.

questions.question: You ……………………….. me you weren’t coming.
questions.description: Should have + past participle can be used to express some past ideas.

questions.question: He ……………………….. arrive any time.
Where is Janet? She …………………….. be in London, Paris or Berlin – nobody knows.
questions.description: Could can express possibility in affirmative clauses.

questions.question: Kashmir ………………………. be very cold in winter.
questions.description: Can indicates behavior typical of a person or thing.

questions.question: He is the chief guest. He ………………………………… to be here on time.
questions.description: Ought is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: …………………………… you lend me a few hundred dollars?
questions.description: Either can or could is possible here. Could is more polite than can.

questions.question: It is dangerous to go out alone at night. You ………………………….. never do it.
If you start in the morning, you ……………………………. reach there by evening.
questions.description: Will is more appropriate here. In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + bare infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: They sell the best pizza in town. You …………………………… definitely try it.
questions.description: Should is often used to give advice.

questions.question: If it rains, we ………………………………. get wet.
If she spoke a little French, she ……………………………. find a better job.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would/could/might + bare infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: He …………………………….. be an introvert during his university days.
questions.description: Used to can be used to talk about past states.

questions.question: ……………………………… you like to come with me?
questions.description: Would is used in polite offers.

questions.question: We …………………………. never throw away anything useful.
I can’t find my phone. I …………………………………… have lost it on the bus.
questions.description: All of these are possible here with slight differences in meaning.

questions.question: Where .................................... she have gone?
questions.description: Either can or could is possible here.

questions.question: They .......................... have left in the morning. (possibility)
questions.description: Might indicates possibility. Will indicates certainty.

questions.question: Since the surgery, he .................................. walk again. (ability)
questions.description: Can shows general ability. Be able to is used to talk about being able to do something on a specific occasion.

questions.question: He suggested that I ........................... accept the offer. (obligation)
questions.description: We use should to make suggestions.

questions.question: You ............................... lied to him.
questions.description: Ought is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: You .................................. told him about my accident. (lack of necessity)
............................ I help you with this? (Offer)
questions.description: Should is used to make offers.

questions.question: He ............................... watch a lot of movies when he was younger. (past habit)
questions.description: Would is used to talk about past habits.

questions.question: I think you ............................. find another job. (suggestion)
questions.description: Should is used in suggestions.

questions.question: You ..................................... invited her to the party. (lack of obligation)
You ...................................... start now.
questions.description: All of these are possible here. Had better is more emphatic.

questions.question: He left late for the train station. He ................................. have missed the train.
questions.description: Both could and might can express possibility in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: If I were you, I ................................. apologize for something I didn't do.
………………………… you solve this puzzle?
questions.description: Can expresses ability.

questions.question: Although she tried, she ………………………….. solve the problem.
questions.description: Could not expresses inability.

questions.question: They ………………………….. have already left.
questions.description: May expresses possibility in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: Who ………………………… it be?
questions.description: Can expresses possibility in questions and negative sentences.

questions.question: No. It ……………………….. be the postman. He has already been.
questions.description: Can expresses possibility in questions and negative sentences.

questions.question: My grandmother is ninety. She …………………………… still read without glasses.
questions.description: Can shows present ability. Could shows past ability.

questions.question: He said that I …………………………… leave if I wanted to.
questions.description: Both could and might can indicate permission.

questions.question: You …………………………. regret this.
questions.description: With second and third person pronouns shall can be used to express a command or threat.

questions.question: I ……………………………. go no matter what.
questions.description: Will indicates determination.

questions.question: She ………………………….. spend hours playing with her dog.
questions.description: We can use will to express characteristic habit.

questions.question: ………………………….. you help me with this?
questions.description: Will is often used in polite requests.

questions.question: I …………………………… pay for your drinks.
questions.description: Will is used in promises.

questions.question: …………………….. you mind moving a bit?
questions.description: Would is used in polite requests.

questions.question: …………………… you lend me your vacuum cleaner?
You ……………………….. not repeat this.
questions.description: Shall can express an order when used with second and third person pronouns.

questions.question: You ……………………….. pay for this.
questions.description: When used with second and third person pronouns, shall can indicate a threat.

questions.question: ………………………… I call the doctor?
All students ………………………… submit their assignments by Friday.
questions.description: Should indicates obligation.

questions.question: You …………………………… leave early if you are not feeling well.
questions.description: Either can or may is possible here.

questions.question: You ………………………….. not have done this to me.
questions.description: The expression should not have is used to criticize people for doing things.

questions.question: The workers asked if they ………………………… leave early.
I ………………………… sing better when I was younger.
questions.description: We use could to indicate past ability.

questions.question: If I knew his name, I ………………………. tell you.
questions.description: In the second conditional we use a simple past in the if-clause and would + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: He hung up before I ............................. say a word.
Anyone ………………………. do this. (Ability)
questions.description: We use can to express ability.

questions.question: I ……………………….. have married her if I had wanted to. (Unrealized past ability)
questions.description: Could have + past participle can be used to talk about past events that did not happen.

questions.question: We ………………………. go swimming on the weekend. (Possibility)
questions.description: May is used to indicate possibility.

questions.question: I was so angry I ………………………… have slapped him.
questions.description: Could have + past participle can be used to talk about past events that did not happen.

questions.question: One day, it ………………………. be possible to live on other planets. (Future prediction)
questions.description: We use will to simply predict future.

questions.question: Tropical areas ………………………… be very warm throughout the year. (Possibility)
questions.description: We use can to talk about theoretical possibility.

questions.question: Epidemics ……………………….. break out any day. (Theoretical possibility)
questions.description: We use can to talk about theoretical possibility.

questions.question: ‘There is the doorbell.’ ‘Who ……………………………. it be?’
‘Where is Janet?’ ‘She ………………………… be in the basement.’
questions.description: Can is not used to talk about logical possibility in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: ‘What ………………………….. we do now?’
questions.description: Shall is used to ask for suggestions.

questions.question: I ……………………….. see something over there.
I ………………………. help but laugh.
…………………….. you mind posting this letter for me?
questions.description: Would is used in polite requests.

questions.question: …………………… you lend me your bicycle?
questions.description: Will is used in polite requests.

questions.question: You ……………………….. not come to my door again.
questions.description: Shall can express an order when used with second and third person pronouns.

questions.question: You ……………………….. regret this.
questions.description: When used with second and third person pronouns, shall can express a threat.

questions.question: What ……………………….. we do now?
questions.description: Shall can be used to request instruction.

questions.question: Parents ………………………… teach their children to be honest.
questions.description: Should expresses duty.

questions.question: He …………………………. take rest if he is tired.
questions.description: We can use can to express permission.

questions.question: You ………………………….. have told me before borrowing my car.
questions.description: The expression should have is used to criticize people for not doing things.

questions.question: The students asked if they ………………………. go home early.
I ………………………… run faster when I was younger.
questions.description: Could indicates past ability.

questions.question: You …………………………. not light a match. Gas is leaking.
questions.description: Must indicates prohibition.

questions.question: I …………………………. smoke before I fell ill.
questions.description: We use used to to talk about past habits.
